grow.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to increase in amount, size, number, or strength
grow.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Support for Mr Thompson is growing.
A growing number of people are taking part-time jobs.
Fears are growing for the crew’s safety.
There is growing concern about climate change.
Sales of new cars grew by 10% last year.
The number of students at the college has grown from 200 to over 500.
a city that is still growing in size
Skiing has really grown in popularity.
grow.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to make a business or part of a business bigger and more successful
grow.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We want to grow the export side of the business.
grow.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to become bigger, taller etc over a period of time in the process of becoming an adult
grow.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: You’ve really grown since I last saw you.
Victor seemed to grow taller every day.
Stan grew two inches in six months.
grow.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if plants grow, they exist and develop in a natural way
grow.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: a tree which will grow well in most types of soil
The plants grow wild (=grow without anyone looking after them) by the river.
grow.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to make plants or crops develop and produce fruit or flowers
grow.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Many families own plots of land to grow food.
Britain grows 6,000,000 tonnes of potatoes a year.
The growing season is from April to September.
grow.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: if you grow your hair or nails, you do not cut them
grow.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I’ve decided to grow my hair long.
grow.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: when hair or nails grow, they become longer
grow.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to change and become different quite slowly
grow.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Her tastes have changed as she’s grown older.
Donna has grown tired of being a model.
Gradually, Fiona’s eyes grew used to the darkness  (=she gradually became able to see a little better).
grow.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to gradually change your opinions and have a feeling that you did not have before
grow.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: After a while the kids grew to like Mr Cox.
the city he had grown to love
grow.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to gradually become better, bigger etc
grow.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: She’s grown tremendously as a musician.
grow.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to increase in amount, size, or degree
grow.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Seaman grew rapidly, becoming one of the largest advertisers in the New York area.
As the US starts to grow again, it will be a more attractive place in which to invest.
In the past 12 months, the labor force has grown by around 60,000.
grow.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if you grow a business activity, you make it bigger
grow.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: We want to grow the export side of the business.
